normalised: So, you're settling in for chai and samosas, maybe about to watch the latest episode of "Anupamaa," and BAM! Darkness. Yes, friends, load shedding has decided to grace us with its unwelcome presence. It's like that uninvited relative who shows up during Diwali and eats all the mithai.

normalised: Load shedding, for those blissfully unaware or who've been living under a solar-powered rock, is essentially planned electricity outages. The power company, usually our good old state electricity board, like, say, B E S C O M in Bangalore or M S E B in Maharashtra, intentionally cuts off power supply to certain areas for a specified duration. Why, you ask? Usually because the demand for electricity exceeds the available supply. Imagine trying to squeeze a liter of milk into a half-liter bottle – things are gonna spill, right? Same principle.

normalised: Now, the reasons behind this shortage can be varied. Sometimes it's due to maintenance work at power plants, other times it's because of unexpected breakdowns. Sometimes, during peak summer months in places like Rajasthan or Uttar Pradesh, everyone cranks up their A C s, causing a massive surge in demand that the grid just can't handle. Monsoon failures also lead to power cuts as hydropower generation takes a hit. Remember the two thousand and twelve India blackout? That was a whopper, impacting hundreds of millions!

normalised: The impact? Well, it's far reaching, from messing up your evening plans (bye bye, "Anupamaa"!) to disrupting businesses and causing traffic jams when traffic lights go kaput. Small businesses, especially those reliant on electricity for production or services (think internet cafes or small-scale manufacturing units in places like Surat or Ludhiana), suffer significant losses. Even studies get hampered. Imagine trying to cram for your I I T-J E E exam by candlelight! It's like something out of the film "Lagaan," where they had other problems to deal with but, you get the idea, no power, no progress!

normalised: So, what can we do? Conserve energy, for starters. Switch off lights and appliances when not in use. Invest in energy-efficient appliances. And maybe, just maybe, start lobbying our elected officials to invest more in renewable energy sources and infrastructure upgrades. Maybe one day we'll bid adieu to load shedding for good. Until then, keep that torch handy and your power bank charged! Also, a good book might just come in handy, or maybe play some cards with the family by the light of a Diya.
